captions.text:
February is home to one of the most important
holidays of the year not to forget: Groundhog
Day.

If you live outside of Can-merica then you
might not know what a groundhog is so... here

you go: this is a groundhog. They're basically
giant grumpy squirrels who dig burrows underground.

Burrows large enough, in fact, to occasionally
make their comfy home a structural hazard
to your comfy home.

This explains the first half of their name.
The second half is because they're kind of

fat -- though unlike their fellow Can-mericans
-- when winter arrives they need their excess
weight to go into hibernation.

The story of the holiday is that on February
2nd the wise groundhogs wake from hibernation

to peek out of their burrow and look at the
world. If they see their shadow they go back

inside which predicts six more weeks of winter.
If they don't, then spring will come early.

The holiday started in the 1800s as a Pennsylvania
Dutch custom of weather prediction and today

is celebrated in Canada and 49 of the fifty
states, the exception being Alaska which in

2009 decided to forgo groundhog day in favor
of marmot day.

Outside of Alaska, many groundhogs contend
with each other to be the King of Seasonal

Weather prediction their their main weapon
in this war being their delightful names such
as:

Queen Charlotte and Sir Walter Wally in North
Carolina,
Shubenacadie Sam of Nova Scotia
Staten Island Chuck from New York
French Creek Freddie in West Virginia

And... Gus from Athens Georgia though this
last groundhog is somewhat overshadowed by

his neighbor, General Beauregard Lee, who
one must assume has stylish facial hair and

fans himself on the veranda of his plantation
home while drinking Mint Julep and pining
for the day when the south will rise again.

1,000 miles north of the General, Wiarton
Willie is the groundhog king of Canada, who

throws an annual party to help him stay on
top and make sure that people keep building
epic statues of him.

But, if there could be only one, Punxsutawney
Phil would be him. Not only is his name the

most fun to say but he also has quite a posse
of top-hatted, tuxedoed men who look after
him and call themselves the inner circle.

According to them, Punxsutawney Phil has been
making predictions since the 1880s. Not a

Punxsutawney Phil, mind you, but this Punxsutawney
Phil who is functionally immortal because

of a magic life-extending elixir the inner
circle members prepare for him so that he

can continue to make predictions -- and bring
in tourist revenue -- until the end of time.

He also speaks a language called groundhogese
that only the president of the inner circle
can understand.

If you think that Groundhog day is a dumb,
pointless holiday then, there are two things
you should consider:

1st: you have no sense of fun and 2nd, you
better be careful on Groundhog day, because

in addition to their weather predicting day
jobs, these groundhogs also have the magical

power to trap you in a infinite time loop
until you learn to be less of a jerk.
Happy Groundhog Day�

comments.text:
just a tidbit... There is a pagan holiday called Imbolc (candlemass) that 
falls on feb. 2nd that has an old story that goes with it about an elderly 
woman who would leave her house to gather more lumber for winter on that 
day. she would only leave to get the wood if it was pleasant and sunny and 
not dreary and cloudy, (hence the seeing shadows thing because shadows wont 
cast on cloudy days). this is just research i stumbled across on my own and 
i noticed the connection.  i'm not sure if this is where groundhog's day 
came from but it's a pretty neat coincidence.  a lot of modern holidays 
seem to have pagan influence, like Halloween (Samhien Nov 1st) and 
Christmas (Yule Dec 22) .... suddenly "yuletide" makes sense haha﻿

comments.text:
+Alwin Priven
 You missed the whole point of my last few comments apparently so I am 
going to explain for the last time
1.) If you remove the first line of that code you wrote (while(true)) you 
could have a functional code. But just adding that while loop breaks it.
2.) The code you wrote wouldn't accomplish any of the things you intended 
it to even if it was able to be run in the first place.

comments.author: Alwin Priven

comments.text:
A while(true) loop would make it so that the rest of the code isn't even 
read though. Since the expression is never false, nothing written outside 
the loop block is ever read or ran. So that means nothing else happens. 
Also, I thought we were trying to have the guy relive the same 24 hours, 
not get stuck in a single moment. And with the code you wrote, if the 
person was not a jerk, it would just instantly skip their entire lifetime. 
I don't think our initial plan was to kill people who weren't jerks.
comments.author: Hayda Rinna

comments.text:
+Hayda Rinna yes, it just checks, forever. the while loop is just time 
itself, and then it always checks if the person is a jerk, if he is, the 
day is the same. if he isn't, next day.
comments.author: Alwin Priven

comments.text:
+Alwin Priven
Making a while loop with "true" as its expression literally means "create 
an infinite loop". Since there is no reason for true to suddenly become 
false. The loop would keep executing forever.
The code you wrote would:
Freeze time at the same moment FOREVER if the person is a jerk
and if the person is not a jerk, then the program would reel the time 
towards positive infinity, until the said person dies, after which he/she 
doesn't have a jerk property nor does he/she belong to a jerk class.
If the only condition you are checking is "person==jerk", there is no 
reason for a loop of any kind, just do an "if statement".
comments.author: Hayda Rinna
Alwin Priven

comments.text:
Do..while... and while... do... loops are both present in many programming 
languages.
while (expression) do {statement} /*Only does the statement while the 
expression is true and stops as soon as it is not true. */
do {statement} while (expression) /*Does the statement once BEFORE checking 
if the expression is true or false, after that it is exactly the same as 
the while...do... loop. */
In the way that is seen in the video, it is an infinite loop that never 
leaves the exact moment in which the program was first run. If we are 
trying to make a person relive the same entire day until they stop being a 
jerk and if we have to accomplish this by using a while loop of some kind, 
the "while..do.."loop seems to make more sense, but I would rather make a 
function that is called at midnight or maybe I would add an event listener 
to midnight and then solve this with a simple "if".
comments.author: Hayda Rinna

comments.text:
+מיכאל אלגאוי I'm not sure if that was Braedens point, but the problem with 
the while you == jerk do: today is that you will only experience today if 
you are a jerk, else it will just skip today. In a java program(the only 
language i know) you'd have to write do{today}while(you == jerk); so it 
would always execute it at least once.
